div.p: 18th November
Dr Sir

You will have received before this my little paper for the Royal Society and I hope. it will suit. Enclosed a short abstract, and also another small list of plants not contained in your last year's "Census", among which is one new to South Australia, of which Baron F. v. M. specially charges one to let you know, viz, Carex breviculris which occurs close to Clarendon near the river. It is a small plant & resembles a small Xerotes very much.

In respect of the Anguillaria or Wurmbseae the Baron seems to consider it as W. uniflora but has reserved it. As to the Viola with blue flowers and serrated narrow rhimboidal leaves, he only regards it as a variety of V. hederaceae, from which it seems to be separated widely in its habits, the latter being solitary and in dry scrub lands.
In the matter of three very distinct Pimeleas, he classes them all this time as P. humilis, while on a former occasion he called them P. glauca!

[Aprossus], there is a red flowering Banksia along Tilly's Swamp on the Road to Mt Gambier which the Baron has been
seen? check.
there, but not known to science, could you get it? I have seen it there many years ago (about 1861 & 2), & mentioned it to the Baron, hence the inference.

Some of the quartzitic sandstones & tulease shales appear very likely to offer evidence of fossils. I have a piece of shale, weathered, which exhibits, what resembles purtince of casl, of something like an aphrodites; and a fragment of sandstone showing appearance of pencil sketch opposite.
sketch included on facing page but rather faint on p/c.
Another fragment contains a cavity resembling hollow left by a distorted Echinaderue.

Only think, the white & pink flowered liliaceaous plant we found on the hill above Magill in a large dense patch & you were disposed to consider as an introduced garden plant the Baron idenitifies as Bulbine semiharbala! There is as much resemblance bewteen it and the small yellow flowered plant of that name I saw over hundreds of square miles at the Peninsula as between a Swan and a duck. The total Plants I have identified up to date is above 220, but only about 196 in the collection, besides a number in store.

This plant is found in the sandy & scrubby Tertiary country as well as the hill plateaux, generally singly, but sometimes 2 or 3 together in open spots near trees or shrubs. It is 6-9 in. high; its single leaf narrow & […],

about 3 inches. There are usually two flowers, the lower one having the larger pedicule this opening above that terminating the main stalk; colour of petal deep sky-blue. It is rare. Baron F. v. Mueller cites it from the Murray, Victoria.
